unnormalised: Hey everyone, I've always been a bit confused about time zones, especially when coordinating with friends and family across India. Like, if it's 9 AM in Mumbai, what time is it in Guwahati? They're both in India, so it should be straightforward, right? Turns out, not so much. I always get slightly messed up.
normalised: Hey everyone, I have always been a bit confused about time zones, especially when coordinating with friends and family across India. Like, if it's nine A-M in Mumbai, what time is it in Guwahati? They are both in India, so it should be straightforward, right? Turns out, not so much. I always get slightly messed up.

unnormalised: We're all under Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. So, technically, everywhere in India should be the same time, no matter where you are. That's why you won't hear people saying "Oh, it's X time in Kolkata but Y time in Chennai." It's just IST everywhere. And that makes things a lot less complicated than trying to juggle multiple time zones like they do in the US!
normalised: We are all under Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five thirty. So, technically, everywhere in India should be the same time, no matter where you are. That is why you will not hear people saying "Oh, it's X time in Kolkata but Y time in Chennai." It's just I-S-T everywhere. And that makes things a lot less complicated than trying to juggle multiple time zones like they do in the U-S!

unnormalised: However, sometimes when talking to folks abroad, the confusion arises. For example, if someone in London (GMT+1 during British Summer Time) wants to call my cousin in Delhi at 2 PM their time, it'll be 6:30 PM here. It's just adding the hours. And if someone from New York (EST which is GMT-5), says they want to call at 10:00 AM their time it's 7:30 PM here.
normalised: However, sometimes when talking to folks abroad, the confusion arises. For example, if someone in London (G-M-T plus one during British Summer Time) wants to call my cousin in Delhi at two P-M their time, it will be six thirty P-M here. It's just adding the hours. And if someone from New York (E-S-T which is G-M-T minus five), says they want to call at ten A-M their time it's seven thirty P-M here.

unnormalised: Remember to account for Daylight Saving Time (DST) in countries that observe it, because that can throw things off. And IST is the same all year round. This little detail can make planning calls and meetings a bit easier.
normalised: Remember to account for Daylight Saving Time (D-S-T) in countries that observe it, because that can throw things off. And I-S-T is the same all year round. This little detail can make planning calls and meetings a bit easier.

unnormalised: So, short story long, within India, no worries about time zones! But keep GMT+5:30 in mind when dealing with international calls. Hope this clears things up! Also, you can use websites and apps to convert the time. It's a pretty easy way to do it!
normalised: So, short story long, within India, no worries about time zones! But keep G-M-T plus five thirty in mind when dealing with international calls. Hope this clears things up! Also, you can use websites and apps to convert the time. It's a pretty easy way to do it!
